content.description: Start sit on the left side of the boulder, traverse right then go straight up on the center of the boulder.
content.location: Walk inside the woods, stay low and you will found a nice trail, follow that, the boulder is on the right side just before the cliff line

content.description: The best problem of this area, sit start then follow the obvious and very cool line up the dihedral crack to a dyno finish.
content.protection: 2 pads minimum and a good spotter. 4 for comfort,  final dyno has a chance for falling off the large boulder without a good spotter.
content.location: Follow the ATV trail pass the library until almost at the house, then hike 10-15 minutes up the steep hill northeast along the cliff line (trail is off the cliff line about 100 feet east). At the top of the hill on the left side is an obvious roof with a large 20+ foot tall boulder you can walk on. Go up between two rocks under the roof then left to get up to. Problem is the farthest obvious dihedral crack line.Alternatively,  Park at cemetery and head north/ north east. Can walk low towards library and then hike up, or head straight up the hill.

content.description: Sit star on a big crack bottom right then climb up the cool arete to slopey open hands on the lip. Final hold is a jug in line with the tree, mantle up to finish.
content.protection: 3 pads minimum. 5 for comfort,  more if possible.
content.location: Once at the library, head south along the cliff line (can use the ATV trail), follow the trail to a big caves, this problem is the first small cave left of the big cave.

content.description: Very cool roof, start stend on two crimp just under the roof, rich the crack under the roof then traverse out and fight the top out.
content.location: When you start to see the first boulder on this area go up right to the top of the hill, you will see a cliff line after 200 feet, the problem is inside between two rocks around the oblivious big first boulder you will fond

content.description: Nice area with many boulders, and many still needing to be projected. Many boulders are close to people's houses so climb like a ninja and not an Elk in heat.
